comment info:
Alpha Group:
One thing to notice is the timeline of this graph: only 10 years with such significant changes makes this data set more challenging to comprehend because of the sporadic nature of this graph. This could be due to individual events that happened to cause such drastic changes. For example, notice that the graph's data was retrieved from Dallas, Texas; the resurgence in total animals from 2017-present could be explained by the mass migration of animals to Dallas from Houston as a result of Hurricane Harvey's massive amount of destruction from it's Category 4 strength. Another thing to notice is the amount of animals being euthanized is on a steady decline. Pet stores are now selling more shelter animals as opposed to purebred. The increase in adoption rates could be caused by the rise of young families who are breaking traditional norms to adopt a dog or cat before having children.

name: Team Omega
comment info: First and foremost, we notice a steady decline in euthanization throughout the past few years. This is due to an increase in pet safety laws and PETA's growing influence. Overall, the downward trend is due to a decrease in animals going to this Dallas shelter. This can be attributed to movies like A Dog's Purpose and the cost of pet food. The sudden increase of pets in 2017 is due to Hurricane Harvey. The hurricane did not hit Dallas, and so, animals from shelters in the area that was hit were transferred to other shelters around the country (and even more so through the state). As a result, people were moved to adopt more sad, poor animals homeless by the hurricane. We wonder why there was an increase in animals who were released and what that means. We also are curious to know what this graph would look like today. Would there be an increase in adoptions? Would there be a decrease in animals arriving to the shelter? We love the title from Mrs. Lane from ELP Teacher: "It's Raining Cats and Dogs"

Delta group,
We noticed a steady decrease in all categories up until the year 2016, where everything but adoption rates and returning rates to owners decreased, and the aforementioned categories rose with the rise in populations entering the Dallas animal services. However, regardless of the year, very little dogs or cats were released. If this graph is linear, then the trendline shows that soon there will be no need to Euthanize. I wonder if this is only a problem in Dallas, or if there used to be so many killing of dogs and cats elsewhere.
